description: {"blocks":[{"key":"bp56u","text":"This protocol is for a semi-manual method for read demultiplexing, as used after my presentation Sequencing DNA with Linux Cores and Nanopores to work out the number of reads captured by different barcodes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":97,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fhica","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"56rl3","text":"Input: reads as a FASTQ file, barcode sequences as a FASTA file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6gv8j","text":"Output: reads split into single FASTQ files per target [barcode]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dv1p3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"992k1","text":"Note: barcode / adapter sequences are not trimmed by this protocol","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

groups.title: High molecular weight DNA extraction from all kingdoms

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6t07s","text":"Prepare a FASTA file containing barcode sequences (see attached FASTA file). To reduce the chance of mismatched adapters, this should only contain the barcode sequences. That restriction means this approach will not work for short reads, where the barcode sequences are very likely to occur within sequences.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":134,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"adgi5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"90e9n","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"fjsgn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"6D43E4F0241511E9B5045FC0FC2F250F","id":"35092","original_name":"barcode_base.fa","placeholder":"/img/extensions/file.png","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/pr-journal/bciwa.fa"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c4rvc","text":"Prepare the LAST index for the barcode file. Following Martin Frith's recommendation, the '-uNEAR' seeding scheme is used to slightly increase sensitivity. This will generate seven additional files of the form \u003cindex name\u003e.XXX:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":55,"length":29}],"data":[]},{"key":"4iqe6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d0d8t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"71quq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"28ujk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"9EFA2B40E4CB11E98A3FA99156212B2C","url":"https://github.com/mcfrith/last-rna/blob/master/last-long-reads.md#option-1-prepare-a-genome-without-repeat-masking"}},"1":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2b4pm","text":"lastdb -uNEAR barcode_base.fa barcode_base.fa","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"881nq","text":"Prepare a substitution matrix for barcode mapping. The default substitution matrix is swayed too much by INDELs in the barcode sequences, so here's one that I've developed using last-train using super-accuracy Nanopore reads called using Guppy v5:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4sqa8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38cl9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2kv7s","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cdlbc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3jsak","text":"I generated this matrix from the following command:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5svti","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f8btk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dppdj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"n7q4","text":"This matrix has a small penalty for opening gaps (i.e. insertions and deletions), and a smaller penalty for inserting them. Insertions and deletions are considered to be equally likely in the barcode region. It also has a moderate penalty for A/G transition variants, and a higher penalty for C/T transition variants (but still lower than other substitution penalties).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8ulrs","text":"#last -Q 1","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"do8d0","text":"#last -t4.34158","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4a4q6","text":"#last -a 31","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"85jsj","text":"#last -A 35","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eqor4","text":"#last -b 4","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d6cpm","text":"#last -B 3","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"k4v2","text":"#last -S 1","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eudpq","text":"# score matrix (query letters = columns, reference letters = rows):","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"rbig","text":"       A      C      G      T","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cf8u5","text":"A      8    -18    -14    -22","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4lvvm","text":"C    -18      7    -20    -23","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5p84s","text":"G    -14    -20      6    -24","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7vign","text":"T    -22    -23    -24      4","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"file","mutability":"","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"9CBA91D0637C11ECA3DD273D99091A0C","id":195062,"original_name":"bc.mat","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f8ryjpt6.mat"}},"2":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c8g2k","text":"last-train --matsym -Q 1 -P 10 barcode_base.fa reads_all.fastq.gz \u003e bc.mat","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4g63k","text":"Combine all input reads into a single file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2qqgl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dqkpu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"pnsp","text":"Note: I'm using the pipe viewer command pv to produce a progress indicator while the command is running. If this command is not available, it can be replaced with cat with no change in function (apart from not showing progess).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":40,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":163,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ciit0","text":"pv ../called_all/*.fastq | gzip \u003e reads_all.fastq.gz","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"36thi","text":"Use LAST, including FASTQ quality scores for substitution (-Q 1), using the pre-defined substitution matrix to map the reads. In this example, it is distributed over 10 processing threads (-P 10). Here maf-convert is used to convert to a single line per match, cut retains only the barcode and read IDs, and uniq is used to make sure that multiple same barcodes per read (e.g. for reverse / complement barcodes at each end) will not produce duplicates:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":202,"length":11},{"style":"italic","offset":261,"length":3},{"style":"italic","offset":308,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1kk2u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"kmjt","text":"For a more stringent search, lastal can do an overlap match (-T 1) rather than the default local match, which will make sure that only the ends of the barcode are matched (hopefully the entire barcode) when demultiplexing. The downside is that this is more likely to drop reads due to slight mismatches in the barcode portion of the read:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"amqb7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7ng03","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ejlg","text":"Stringency can also be altered by adjusting the query letters per random alignment setting (-D \u003cvalue\u003e, 1e6 by default). Lowering this number will produce more matches, at the expense of more false positive matches:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7o7sn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rs5d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5bo7v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di01s","text":"The output of this command will be a gzipped tab-separated 2-column file with barcode names in the first column, and read IDs in the second column.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bf8v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4248b","text":"lastal -Q 1 -P10 -p bc.mat barcode_base.fa \u003c(pv reads_all.fastq.gz) | \\","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1tb6f","text":"  maf-convert -n tab | cut -f 2,7 | sort | uniq | \\","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eml1t","text":"  gzip \u003e barcode_assignments.txt.gz","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":7,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bp70","text":"lastal -T 1 -Q 1 -P10 -p bc.mat barcode_base.fa \u003c(pv reads_all.fastq.gz) | \\","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"23p2m","text":"  maf-convert -n tab | cut -f 2,7 | sort | uniq | \\\n  gzip \u003e barcode_assignments.txt.gz","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":6,"offset":7,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3qvbv","text":"lastal -D 1e5 -Q 1 -P10 -p bc.mat barcode_base.fa \u003c(pv reads_all.fastq.gz) | \\","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1vbkk","text":"  maf-convert -n tab | cut -f 2,7 | sort | uniq | \\","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fj1s9","text":"  gzip \u003e barcode_assignments.txt.gz","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4ovbn","text":"For each discovered barcode, using the appropriate read category assignment file, find the corresponding read IDs, then extract those IDs out of the read FASTQ file. This uses one of my scripts, fastx-fetch.pl, to do this directly from a FASTQ file. The '-lengths' command-line parameter also outputs sequence lengths for each read (see next step):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":255,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":195,"length":14}],"data":[]},{"key":"1mjlq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6h5if","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"9kbrj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"f6dnh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ce3nj","text":"Note: this demultiplexing code will only by default put reads into a barcode bin if they have a single unique barcode sequence detected. Otherwise, they will be put into a 'BCchim' bin if multiple adapters are detected (i.e. a chimeric read), or a 'BCmiss' bin if no adapters are detected. If these reads should be duplicated and put in one bin per barcode, then the -chimeric option can be added to the command arguments:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":367,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dsh4d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"crlr7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7tvit","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"907DA0E0241B11E9B5045FC0FC2F250F","url":"https://gitlab.com/gringer/bioinfscripts/blob/master/fastx-fetch.pl"}},"1":{"type":"file","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"22FAE380B71311E9903F3F1BAFB0F8DF","id":45547,"original_name":"fastx-fetch.pl","placeholder":"/img/extensions/file.png","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/d3caf5d2f980d165712bb8262c51687a45460e9aedd9631ff736620da233c966/bnrmjpt6.pl"}},"2":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"62ab0","text":"mkdir -p demultiplexed","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e0vhn","text":"fastx-fetch.pl -lengths -demultiplex barcode_assignments.txt.gz \\","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b4490","text":"  -prefix 'demultiplexed/reads' \u003c(pv reads_all.fastq.gz) \u003e barcode_counts.txt","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"3":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3arck","text":"mkdir -p demultiplexed","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":64,"style":"bold"}],"key":"75h93","text":"fastx-fetch.pl -lengths -demultiplex barcode_assignments.txt.gz -chimeric \\","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dgk0j","text":"  -prefix 'demultiplexed/reads' \u003c(pv reads_all.fastq.gz) \u003e barcode_counts.txt","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"46smt","text":"The lengths output from the demultiplexing step can be fed into another one of my scripts, length-plot.r, in order to display length-based QC plots:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":4,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":91,"length":13}],"data":{}},{"key":"adt8r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pjq6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dj19d","text":"As output, this produces a multi-page PDF file, Sequence_curves.pdf. Here are some examples of the plots that are produced:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":48,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"180bj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7574h","text":"1.
